item.title: Hugo Atom feeds with XSLT
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Defining the Atom feed format
  • Adding style
  • Putting it together

RSS and Atom web feeds are great for subscribing to content: they are standardized and unobtrusive to readers.

Hugo is a free and open source static site generator that makes building a blog with web feed support easy. By default, it creates a RSS 2.0 feed, but in this post, I introduce creating an Atom feed instead. Atom is a newer XML-based format with a more standardized specification, meaning it should work as expected with more feed reader implementations.

The inspiration (and code examples) for much of this post come from:

  • @lpar’s Github Gist on producing Hugo Atom feeds
  • Andrew Stiefel’s article on styling with XSLT

Defining the Atom feed format

The first steps is to configure Hugo by modifying the main config.toml configuration file to output Atom pages. The following configuration (added to your file) tells Hugo:

  • that the application/atom data type has a suffix of .xml
  • that the "Atom" output format has the media type defined above and the name atom (its full filename will be atom.xml).
  • to output the home page of the site in the HTML and Atom formats.
# Define media type
[mediaTypes]
  [mediaTypes."application/atom"]
    suffixes = ["xml"] # suffix key was deprecated

# Define output format
[outputFormats.Atom]
  mediaType = "application/atom"
  baseName = "atom"
  isPlainText = false

# Define additional outputs for home page (index)
[outputs]
  home = [ "HTML", "Atom" ]

Second, create a index.atom.xml template file in your theme’s layouts directory. This template file should use Hugo’s templating syntax, similar to Jekyll’s, to dynamically modify its contents. I used the one contributed by @dianoetic in the Github Gists thread with a few modifications:

  • In my case, Hugo would safe encode the < as < for the XML string <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>, so I had to pipe it to safeHTML.
  • I included {{ .Description }} as the content block of the theme instead of the full article.
{{- $pctx := . -}}
{{- if .IsHome -}}{{ $pctx = .Site }}{{- end -}}
{{- $pages := slice -}}
{{- if or $.IsHome $.IsSection -}}
{{- $pages = $pctx.RegularPages -}}
{{- else -}}
{{- $pages = $pctx.Pages -}}
{{- end -}}
{{- $limit := .Site.Config.Services.RSS.Limit -}}
{{- if ge $limit 1 -}}
{{- $pages = $pages | first $limit -}}
{{- end -}}

{{ printf `<?xml version="1.0" encoding="%s"?>` "UTF-8" | safeHTML }}

<feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">
  <title>{{ if eq  .Title  .Site.Title }}{{ .Site.Title }}{{ else }}{{ with .Title }}{{.}} on {{ end }}{{ .Site.Title }}{{ end }}</title>
  <link href="{{ .Permalink }}index.xml" rel="self"/>
  <link href="{{ .Permalink }}"/>
  {{ if not .Date.IsZero }}
    <updated>{{ .Date.Format "2006-01-02T15:04:05-07:00" | safeHTML }}</updated>
  {{ end }}
  <id>{{ .Permalink }}</id>
  {{ with .Site.Author.name }}
    <author>
      <name>{{.}}</name>
      {{ with $.Site.Author.email }}
        <email>{{.}}</email>
      {{end}}
    </author>
  {{end}}
  <generator>Hugo -- gohugo.io</generator>
  {{ range $pages }}
    <entry>
      {{ `<title type="html"><![CDATA[` | safeHTML }}{{ .Title }}]]></title>
      <link href="{{ .Permalink }}"/>
      <id>{{ .Permalink }}</id>
      {{ with $.Site.Author.name }} 
        <author>
          <name>{{.}}</name>
        </author>
      {{ end }}
      <published>{{ .Date.Format "2006-01-02T15:04:05-07:00" | safeHTML }}</published>
      <updated>{{ .Lastmod.Format "2006-01-02T15:04:05-07:00" | safeHTML }}</updated>
      {{ if .Description }}
        {{ `<content type="html"><![CDATA[` | safeHTML }}{{ .Description }}]]></content>
      {{ end }}
    </entry>
  {{ end }}
</feed>

Make sure that config.toml has a [Author] block like so for the template to fill in your name and email:

[Author]
name = "John Doe"
email = "johndoe@email.com"

Congrats! After these steps, an Atom feed should be generated at /atom.xml of your site. This can be linked to by your home page.

Adding style

The XSLT standard defines a method of transforming XML documents into other formats that is supported in most browsers. We’ll use it to transfer the Atom feed into an HTML web page for viewers that stumble upon it and are not feed readers. Hugo pipes allow us to use templating in our XSLT file so that it can link back to our home page.

First, create a template file in the /assets/css/ directory from the root of your theme with the name template.xsl. This file can be defined according to the XSLT specification to insert HTML elements for ocurrances of an XML element. I used Andrew Stiefel’s blog’s preview to make the file below:

<xsl:stylesheet
  version="1.0"
  xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"
  xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"
  exclude-result-prefixes="atom"
>
  <xsl:output method="html" version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" indent="yes"/>
  <xsl:template match="/">
    <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
      <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"/>
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, maximum-scale=1"/>
        <title>Web Feed • <xsl:value-of select="atom:feed/atom:title"/></title>
        <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="{{ (resources.Get "css/your.css").RelPermalink }}" />
      </head>
      <body>
        <section>
          <xsl:apply-templates select="atom:feed" />
        </section>
        <main id="content">
          <h3>Web feed preview</h3>
          <p><strong>Subscribe</strong> to this blog's latest posts by copying the URL of this Atom feed from the address bar to a <a href="https://aboutfeeds.com/">newsreader</a> app.</p>
          <h3>Recent Items</h3>
          <ul id="posts">
            <xsl:apply-templates select="atom:feed/atom:entry" />
          </ul>
        </main>
        {{ partial "footer.html" . }}
      </body>
    </html>
  </xsl:template>

  <xsl:template match="atom:feed">
    <header id="banner">
      <h2>
        <a href="{{ .Site.BaseURL }}"><xsl:value-of select="atom:title"/></a>
      </h2>
    </header>
  </xsl:template>

  <xsl:template match="atom:entry">
    <li>
      <a target="_blank">
        <xsl:attribute name="href">
          <xsl:value-of select="atom:id"/>
        </xsl:attribute>
        <xsl:value-of select="atom:title"/>
        <small><time><xsl:value-of select="atom:updated" /></time></small>
      </a>
    </li>
  </xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

Notice how with templating, {{ (resources.Get "css/your.css").RelPermalink }} can point to your own CSS styling sheet to match the aesthetic of your website, while {{ .Site.BaseURL }} links your homepage back to the web feed and partial elements like {{ partial "footer.html" . }} can also be included.

Putting it together

When your template.xslt file is finished, make sure to include it in the atom.xml feed by adding the below two lines right after {{ printf "UTF-8" | safeHTML }} in the index.atom.xml file:

{{ $css := (resources.Get "css/template.xsl") | resources.ExecuteAsTemplate "feed.xsl" . }}

{{ printf `<?xml-stylesheet href="%s" type="text/xsl"?>` $css.RelPermalink | safeHTML }}

This will apply the templating to the XSLT template file before adding the link to it as a .RelPermalink. Now, your site will have both an /atom.xml feed and styling applied by the browser whenever a user visits it.

item.title: Personal man pages
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • The setup
  • On macOS with the Touch Bar

Recently, a Hacker News post was created about “Um,” a tool to create your own man pages. One comment by @pjungwir was interesting:

. . . If you don’t want to install anything new, you can also write your own man pages with a personal “man section”. Just do something like this in your shell:

export MANPATH="$MANPATH:$HOME/man"
export MANSECT="1:n:l:8:3:2:3posix:3pm:3perl:5:4:9:6:7:pj"

Here I’ve added the “pj” section (my initials).

Then I have files like ~/man/manpj/postgres.pj or ~/man/manpj/ssl.pj. I can say man pj postgres to see my own notes. My own collection goes back to 2001 or so. I feel lucky that early on I started putting notes into something so portable. It’s one of the few things that has always moved with me to new machines. It is here: https://github.com/pjungwir/manpj/

Notes stored in this way would be easily accessible, searchable as plain text, and in one syncable directory. Smart, and useful! For Markdown writers like me, I found that a pandoc and Makefile setup could convert all my Markdown notes into the man page format, taking inspiration and code from this post by Eddie Antonio Santos.

The setup

For man to find my custom man pages, I opted to use the “0” section (not used by any shipped documentation) and to store any created man pages in the ~/man directory. To that end, I added the below into my ~/.bashrc.

# enable custom man pages
export MANPATH="$MANPATH:$HOME/man"
export MANSECT="1:n:l:8:3:2:3posix:3pm:3perl:5:4:9:6:7:0"

I then created the following tree:

man/
├── Makefile
├── man0/
├── markdown/
└── README.md

In this setup, man0/ stores generated man pages while markdown/ stores source notes. The final step was to create a Makefile for easy converting, provided the pandoc binary was installed and callable.


PANDOC ?= pandoc

# Modify to reference man pages from section other than zero
MANSECTION ?= 0

# Source and output directories
SRC := markdown
OUT := man$(MANSECTION)

# Find all source markdown files to convert
TARGETS := $(wildcard $(SRC)/*.md)

# Generate file paths of files after conversion
OBJECTS := $(patsubst %.md,%.$(MANSECTION),$(subst $(SRC),$(OUT),$(TARGETS)))

# Define man page conversion commands
MANPAGE.md = $(PANDOC) --standalone $(PANDOCFLAGS) --to man

$(OUT)/%.$(MANSECTION): $(SRC)/%.md
	$(MANPAGE.md) $< -o $@

# Default make target: convert all markdown files
.PHONY: all
all: $(OBJECTS)

# Delete generated man pages in output directory
clean:
	rm $(OUT)/*.$(MANSECTION)

GNU make and pandoc must be installed before the setup can run. For Debian/Ubuntu (you will probably need to run with sudo):

$ apt update
$ apt install make # or build-essential, other tools to build
$ apt install pandoc && apt install groff

After installing these necessary tools and using this directory structure and the corresponding Makefile, I could run make all to convert all Markdown files in the ~/man/markdown directory into corresponding roff man pages stored in man0. These pages could then be displayed by the man pager: for example, man 0 grep would display any personal notes about grep stored in ~/man/markdown/grep.md. Sweet!

On macOS with the Touch Bar

This setup also works with macOS using some modifications. First, on macOS changes to .bashrc should instead be written in a created .bash_profile file. Secondly, the command line tools can be installed with a tool like Homebrew.

On many Macbooks, the default Terminal app (and iTerm2) allow users to lookup man pages quickly with a control on the Touch Bar. However, it does not use the environmental variables set in a previous step, as explained by an answer on the Apple StackExchange by jaume

. . . When you look for a man page by pressing the “Open man Page for Selection” option in the Touch Bar, a process like the following is executed:

login -pfq <username> /usr/bin/man -P ul <command>

where:

  • username is your username
  • command is the command whose man page you want to display

login starts man directly, and it is not aware of the value of the MANPATH variable.

The solution is to “add a MANPATH entry to /private/etc/man.conf.” For my setup, I had to:

  • Add the line MANPATH /Users/<username>/man (or wherever the man directory is stored)
  • Modify the line MANSECT 1:1: . . . to include :0 at the end, like the exported variables in .bash_profile.

Afterwards, any custom man pages created will be accessible with the man page Touch Bar control.
